description: High entropy DNS query for 'youtu.be' may indicate use of DNS tunneling for C2 communication
Forwarding of high entropy domain 'youtu.be' to external DNS resolver (8.8.8.8) supports possibility of DNS-based C2 or tunneling
High entropy DNS query from different internal IPs querying the same domain 'youtu.be', potentially indicating beaconing
Forwarding 'youtu.be' internally (to 192.168.255.254) indicates internal DNS relay for a potentially high entropy domain
DNS reply for 'youtu.be' resolves to legitimate Google IP; no evidence of data exfiltration or tunneling
Another normal DNS reply for 'youtu.be' suggests legitimate web usage; does not match malicious behavior
Low frequency of 'A' DNS queries could point to reconnaissance against internal mail domain or low-and-slow scanning
IMAP login disconnect with no auth attempts may suggest probing or automated brute force testing behavior
Duplicate log entry for disconnected IMAP login event, further indicating potential enumeration or scanning
Repeated event across multiple logs indicates widespread detection of suspicious login behavior
Reverse DNS failed for IP 192.168.130.77; might be scanning without proper DNS setup.
Repeated log entry of reverse DNS failure suggests scanning activity from 192.168.130.77.
Client from 192.168.130.77 denied access to /var/www/html/ — possible probing of restricted directories.
Unauthorized access attempt by 172.17.130.196 to /var/www/html/ suggests directory scanning.
Repeated reverse DNS failure from IP 192.168.130.77; likely part of a broader scan.
Unexpected TLS packet during handshake — could signal a probe or malformed TLS negotiation.
Another reverse DNS failure from the same IP; same behavior, repeated.
403 response to GET /nmaplowercheck1642508249 indicates Nmap NSE HTTP scan attempt.
403 response to POST /sdk using Nmap user agent; suggests automated scanning of application endpoints.
Generic GET / with 403 result from suspicious IP; might be a probing or connectivity test.
403 response to POST request from Nmap Scripting Engine user-agent indicates active probing or enumeration of server endpoints.
403 response from another host using Nmap Scripting Engine user-agent suggests coordinated scanning activity.
Access denied to /HNAP1 path, commonly targeted in router exploit attempts (HNAP protocol vulnerabilities).
Repeated access attempts to /HNAP1 path from another port/IP combination suggest persistence in exploiting a known vulnerable endpoint.
Denied access to /HNAP1 path from a second IP; consistent with vulnerability scanning or targeted exploit probing.
Denied access to root web directory indicates an attempt to enumerate directory structure or access restricted resources.
Access denied to root directory from another IP; confirms enumeration or probing activity.
403 response to GET request targeting WordPress plugin directory using WPScan user-agent implies automated vulnerability scanning.
404 response to HEAD request for a plugin directory indicates plugin enumeration via WPScan.
Repeated HEAD requests for different WordPress plugin paths show pattern of automated scanning by WPScan.
HEAD request targeting WordPress plugin path with user-agent identifying WPScan; plugin 'animated-typing-effect' is probed to detect existence or vulnerabilities.
Probing for 'analytify-analytics-dashboard-widget' plugin using WPScan to identify presence or vulnerabilities in the target WordPress instance.
Scan attempt using WPScan targeting 'post-snippets' plugin path to identify vulnerable or exposed components.
Enumeration of 'post-types-order' plugin directory, indicating reconnaissance for vulnerable plugins.
Scan of 'post-type-switcher' plugin path using HEAD requests, consistent with reconnaissance activity.
Request for 'postmark-approved-wordpress-plugin' plugin path; likely part of an automated vulnerability enumeration.
Scanning for 'postie' plugin using WPScan; consistent with plugin enumeration activity.
Access attempt to 'timthumb.php' script, a historically vulnerable file used in remote code execution attacks on WordPress themes.
Suspicious path double slash to 'timthumb.php', indicating attempt to bypass simple filtering or normalization checks.
Malformed request to 'timthumb.phptimthumb.php' may suggest evasion tactics or accidental tool misconfiguration during scanning.
Use of WPScan user agent and HEAD request to known vulnerable timthumb.php script indicates reconnaissance for WordPress vulnerabilities.
Request to a common WordPress vulnerability path (thumb.php) using WPScan indicates probing for known vulnerable scripts.
Access attempt to .htpasswd file, a sensitive authentication file, likely intended to gather password hashes.
Attempt to bypass detection by accessing '.htpasswd_' instead of '.htpasswd' indicates evasion technique while searching for credentials.
Request with '@' in path is likely part of a fuzzing or path discovery operation testing for vulnerable or misconfigured endpoints.
Unusual path with '~adm' suggests probing for backup/admin directories using fuzzing or automated scanning tools.
Attempted access to info.php under WordPress sitemaps indicates probing for file inclusion or backdoor files.
Use of '+' character in request path to access a likely non-existent resource shows fuzzing behavior for directory/file enumeration.
Access attempt to phpinfo.php suggests enumeration of system environment, often used to identify PHP configuration vulnerabilities.
Path containing '~webmaster' indicates probing for sensitive user directories, possibly to find privilege escalation paths.
Request contains unusual tilde (~) character in a path to a known WordPress directory. This may indicate automated scanning or fuzzing.
Request attempts to access a directory without a default index file, triggering autoindex error. Common in web scanning or recon.
Access attempt to a hidden file (.hta), possibly to identify misconfigurations or exploit local scripts.
Access to a non-existent directory followed by a 301 redirect. Indicates automated scanning or directory enumeration.
Unusual character '+' in request path suggests fuzzing or automated discovery of hidden or non-standard directories.
Access to a plugin directory with 301 redirect response, typical of automated plugin enumeration attempts.
Request for phpinfo.php file, which may reveal server configuration details if it exists. Common in reconnaissance.
Access attempt to another common WordPress subdirectory with redirect response, suggesting continued enumeration.
Access to a likely theme-related subdirectory with 301 redirect; likely part of a WordPress enumeration scan.
Request to a path within a WordPress theme includes a PHP file, which was not found. This suggests probing for file inclusion vulnerabilities.
Access to uncommon path '/wp-content/themes/go/includes/classes/lost+found' with unusual '+' character suggests automated scanning or fuzzing activity for hidden directories.
Attempt to access non-existent PHP script 'info.php' in a likely theme directory indicates probing for vulnerable or misconfigured files.
Attempt to access 'phpinfo.php' suggests attacker trying to find system configuration info via common diagnostic script.
403 status code for access to '/wp-includes/js/tinymce/plugins/hr/' implies unauthorized probing into a potentially sensitive internal plugin directory.
Access to '/admin/~logs' includes uncommon '~' character and resembles a guess at internal naming conventions or temp/hidden directories.
Attempt to access '/admin/~lp' suggests attacker is brute-forcing or fuzzing for internal resource names using tilde prefix.
Access to '/admin/~mail' is likely guessing email-related directories, possibly for webmail or mail logs.
Access to '/admin/~nobody' indicates probing for user-specific hidden folders or common Linux usernames.
Request to '/admin/~operator' suggests fuzzing for system-level or admin-related directories.
Request for 'info.php' in an 'admin/images' path strongly suggests automated probing for diagnostic scripts often used for environment disclosure.
Request to a non-existent path with unusual character '+' in URL, indicating potential reconnaissance or probing for misconfigured paths or resources.
Access attempt to phpinfo.php, often used to enumerate server configuration during reconnaissance or vulnerability assessments.
403 Forbidden response to an attempt to access 'social' directory; suggests probing for restricted or protected resources.
Attempt to access hidden or potentially malicious file '.hta'; 403 response indicates server-side access control.
403 Forbidden request to '.htpasswd', a sensitive file used for HTTP Basic Auth credentials.
Attempt to access a variation of the '.htpasswd' file (.htpasswd_), indicating brute-force or fuzzing of filename variants.
Request includes '@' symbol in path, which is not common in normal resource paths, indicating input fuzzing or directory enumeration.
Use of '~' in path suggests probing for user home directories or hidden resources, a common fuzzing pattern.
Requesting '~admin' path is a typical strategy to identify hidden administrative resources.
Attempt to access .htaccess file, which can contain sensitive configuration and access rules; request was denied by server.
Access attempt to `.htaccess_` file, indicating possible probing for server configuration or credentials.
Access to `.htpasswd` file suggests attacker is trying to locate stored credentials.
Another `.htpasswd_` access attempt, likely automated scanning or fuzzing for credential files.
Request for missing admin.php file; indicates probing for exposed admin panels.
Request for index.php under admin path; suggests directory scanning or brute-force file discovery.
High-entropy GET request to PHP file likely indicates webshell activity or backdoor communication.
High-entropy request to previously accessed webshell with obfuscated parameters, suggesting data exfiltration or control.
Obfuscated parameters sent to same PHP webshell, further indicating controlled data exfil or remote access.
Abnormal frequency of POST requests to AJAX endpoint with headless browser user-agent; suggests automated beaconing.
Unusual spike in normalized CPU usage (from ~0.07 to 1.0), likely due to crypto mining or stress-inducing malware.
High-frequency DNS queries to mmx-ds.cdn.whatsapp.net by 192.168.128.4 may indicate data exfiltration or C2 beaconing behavior over DNS.
Increased frequency of HTTP GET requests to the root of the server using a Firefox user agent may indicate automated reconnaissance or vulnerability scanning.
High-entropy PHP file with suspicious base64 payload in a WordPress uploads directory indicates a potential web shell and remote command execution attempt.
Unusual use of 'su' from web service account 'www-data' to user 'phopkins' suggests unauthorized privilege escalation or lateral movement.
TTY session initiation from www-data to phopkins on /dev/pts/1 indicates a new interactive session from a web service account, which is abnormal.
PAM session opened for phopkins by uid 33 (likely www-data), unusual session behavior indicating unauthorized shell access with escalated privileges.
Audit log shows successful authentication to 'phopkins' account via /bin/su from UID 33 (web context), consistent with privilege escalation.
Audit record confirms new account session opened for 'phopkins' with successful credential verification, potentially from unauthorized actor.
Credential acquisition via PAM setcred for user 'phopkins' by UID 33 indicates potential attempt to maintain access using stolen credentials.
Session open for 'phopkins' via /bin/su confirms shell session escalation from UID 33 (www-data), consistent with web-to-root lateral move.
